info.game_comments:
Jason Keller game 10.
Dave Leach game 1.

(1, 1).clue: Tassel-top, chain & penny are variations of this shoe

(2, 1).clue: Born in Kentucky the year before Lincoln, he became president the same year as Lincoln & died 24 years after Lincoln

(3, 1).clue: This -ism named for a legendary soldier devoted to Napoleon can mean the belief that one's gender is superior

(4, 1).clue: This verse job is awarded on the advice of the prime minister / Whose motives may be underhanded, even sinister

(5, 1).clue: In a kids' book, this Plaza dweller "takes a bawth"

(6, 1).clue: Does this movie character's "Mojo" cologne make you hor--uh... smell good?  Yeah, baby!

(1, 2).clue: Have a unique fashion sense?  Into rubber sole? Then the shoe seen here, used in this sport, is for you

(2, 2).clue: Half of a deadly feud, this family lived primarily in Kentucky; their rivals, in West Virginia

(3, 2).clue: To execute without due process, especially by hanging; it was named for a Virginian who was allowed to do it

(4, 2).clue: Each earning £3.50 a year in a ceremonial post, royal watermen play a part in any state occasion on this river

(5, 2).clue: "A Proud Taste for Scarlet and Miniver" is about 12th century queen Eleanor of this duchy

(6, 2).clue: Bend your nasal passages with this soccer guy's floral scent for ladies or aromatic scent for the blokes

(1, 3).clue: This 4-letter word describes a high-heeled, slip-on shoe with a low-cut or V-shaped throat

(2, 3).clue: In 1883 Thomas Edison showed off his light bulb at the southern exposition in this largest Kentucky city

(3, 3).clue: A Greek god who was half man, half goat & known for causing terror gives us this word for sudden terror

(4, 3).clue: Tom!  Tom!  You can be the son of the queen's this, if dad's musically inclined & in the armed forces

(5, 3).clue: Chapter I of this Lewis Carroll book says, "the glass was beginning to melt away, just like a bright silvery mist"

(6, 3).clue: This singer believes "you are beautiful, no matter what they say", especially with her "Inspire" floral scent

(1, 4).clue: Named for a Buster Brown girl, this low-heeled, patent leather slipper has a single strap over the instep

(2, 4).clue: In 1775 he blazed a trail through Kentucky that became known as the Wilderness Road

(3, 4).clue: The 9th century "Apostle of the Slavs" gave his name to this alphabet used by the Slavs

(4, 4).clue: Not the Master of the House, but the Master of the this is responsible for the sovereign's carriages & certain animals

(5, 4).clue: Sara Crewe is the little title character of this classic by Frances Hodgson Burnett

(6, 4).clue: Everyone nose this Yankee shortstop is "Driven"; now no one can ever say he stinks

(1, 5).clue: You can recognize this French designer's chic shoes by the trademark red soles

(2, 5).clue: Not cotton but this rope-making plant was king in antebellum Kentucky, which grew almost all the USA's supply

(3, 5).clue: This setter dog breed was developed in Scotland & named for the nobleman who popularized it in the early 19th c.

(4, 5).clue: Edmund Halley was the second this "Royal" from 1720 to 1742
(4, 5).correct response: the Astronomer Royal (the Royal Astronomer accepted)

(5, 5).clue: A ravenous insect larva consumes a ton of food & undergoes metamorphosis in this classic by Eric Carle

(6, 5).clue: Get this "U Remind Me" R&B singer's eau de toilette for dad... then explain he's not a guy who works in a movie theater

(1, 1).clue: This title character is sent to fetch Isolde, his uncle King Mark's intended bride

(2, 1).clue: In 1727 this physicist became the first scientist buried in Westminster Abbey

(4, 1).clue: It precedes "tranquility" in the preamble of the Constitution

(5, 1).clue: A dawn event, or a Florida city of 84,000

(6, 1).clue: The "wine" is too warm in the Transylvanian Alps of this country, & why do I have to carry garlic?  Me wanna go home

(1, 2).clue: She's a slave to Amneris, an Egyptian princess

(2, 2).clue: (Sarah of the Clue Crew hovers over Rio de Janeiro, Brazil in a helicopter.)  To switch on floodlights for Christ the Redeemer's dedication in 1931, this radio pioneer sent shortwave signals from Naples

(4, 2).clue: A lump or blob of something, like whipped cream

(5, 2).clue: "Light's glittering morn bedecks the sky", says a hymn for lauds, also called morning this

(6, 2).clue: The summers are nice in this capital of Manitoba--that's when I should have come. Me wanna go home

(1, 3).clue: Alban Berg's 1937 opera is a real doozy, or a real this, the double-talk name of its title character

(2, 3).clue: Scientist & author Temple Grandin overcame this alienating condition, from the Greek for "self" or "same"

(4, 3).clue: It's a file of documents on a particular subject or person

(5, 3).clue: Daylight comes, & it's time for this mix of martial arts & exercise, whose name means "supreme ultimate fist"

(6, 3).clue: Got sunburned visiting the beach of this most populous Brazilian city; home please!

(1, 4).clue: Gingerbread figures turn back into boys & girls when the witch's spell is broken in this opera

(2, 4).clue: In the 2nd century this Alexandrian astronomer catalogued 47 of the 88 constellations we know today

(4, 4).clue: Small "coins" thrown from Mardi Gras floats

(5, 4).clue: When in Rome, Eos, goddess of dawn, went by this name

(6, 4).clue: The seafood was great, the tequila too much in this "True Cross" city on the Gulf of Mexico; me wanna go home

(1, 5).clue: (Alex gives the clue from the Metropolitan Opera in New York.)  The Met's production "Enchanted Island" is a version of "The Tempest", & the costume I'm wearing belongs to this magician, who rules the island

(2, 5).clue: In 1986 Ernst Ruska received the Nobel Prize in Physics for his development of this type of microscope 53 years earlier

(4, 5).clue: This word for a wild brawl is from the name of a Dublin fair

(5, 5).clue: This author says the cells in the skin of some of her characters are "reflective like crystal" & sparkle in daylight

(6, 5).clue: If you can't stand the heat either, then let's caravan out of this fabled city at the center of Mali; me wanna go home

(0, 0).clue: Concluding a 4-book series, his 2004 novel "Folly and Glory" features Kit Carson, William Clark & Jim Bowie
